dt: {bc}a child deprived by death of one or usually both parents

dt.t: He became an {wi}orphan{/wi} when his parents died in a car accident.

dt: {bc}a young animal that has lost its mother
{bc}one deprived of some protection or advantage
{bc}a first line (as of a paragraph) separated from its related text and appearing at the bottom of a printed page or column

et: Middle English {it}orphan, orphen,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French {it}orphayn,{/it} borrowed from Late Latin {it}orphanus,{/it} borrowed from Greek {it}orphanós{/it} "left without parents, child without parents," derivative (with {it}-anos,{/it} noun and adjective suffix) of {it}*orphos{/it} "orphan," going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}3{/inf}órbhos{/it} "person or property turned over (as after a death)," whence also Armenian {it}orb{/it} "orphan," Latin {it}orbus{/it} "deprived by death of a relative, bereaved, orphan," Old Church Slavic {it}rabŭ{/it} "slave," also (from post-Indo-European {it}*orbhós{/it} "one having the inheritance, heir," whence {it}*orbhii̯o-{/it} "of the heir") Old Irish {it}orpe, orbae{/it} "patrimony, heritage," Old English {it}ierfe{/it} "inheritance," Old Saxon {it}erƀi,{/it} Old High German {it}erbi,{/it} Gothic {it}arbi,{/it} and (from Germanic {it}*arbijōn-{/it} "heir") Old English {it}ierfa{/it} "heir," Old High German {it}erbo,{/it} Gothic {it}arbja,{/it} runic Norse {it}arbija{/it}; Indo-European {it}*h{inf}3{/inf}órbhos{/it} perhaps derivative of a verbal base {it}*h{inf}3{/inf}erbh-{/it} "turn, be turned over, undergo transfer" {ma}{mat|orb:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: a child deprived by death of one or usually both parents
a young animal that has lost its mother
one deprived of some protection or advantage
to cause to become an orphan

dt: {bc}a probate court with jurisdiction in some states over the affairs of minors and the administration of estates

shortdef: a probate court with jurisdiction in some states over the affairs of minors and the administration of estates
